results.title: Scribbling kitten
results.brief_description: A kitten named Miaow draws on Mr Bear’s wall watched by two mice friends. When Miaow is finally caught he has to wash the drawings off the wall but when the two mice decide to interfere, the chase is on.

results.title: Screwcutting
results.creator_credit: K. Baron Hartley and Brent Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lathework series”.
The film starts with a short general discussion of screw threads, pitch and shape. The principle of the screw-cutting lathe is illuatrated by mounting a wooden cylinder in the lathe and using a lead pencil instead of a cutting tool.

results.title: Screens and screams [the movie]
results.brief_description: In October 2002, just before opening at Federation Square, ACMI and the City of Melbourne asked the Kids Own Publishing Partnership from Ireland to run a workshop for over 300 primary school students from 8 schools in the city. Each group of kids had a different job to do - some made and filmed shadow puppets, some acted, some digitally animated, and some created an original soundtrack with artists from the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra. The result was the very first Made @ACMI student movie ‘Screens and Screams’
results.description: In October 2002, just before opening at Federation Square, ACMI and the City of Melbourne asked the Kids Own Publishing Partnership from Ireland to run a workshop for over 300 primary school students from 8 schools in the city. results.title: Screens and screams
results.brief_description: Kids’ Own Publishing Partnership will have a series of workshops and resultant exhibition which aims : to promote reading including visual literacy, to engage children in the creative process of working together towards a shared outcome, to produce a number of digital stories, to stimulate publishing in schools beyond the boundaries of the project, to extend children’s experience as readers and writers and illustrators.

results.title: Screening Nuclear Hazard
results.brief_description: An attempt to show how a complicated and sensitive issue is handled by television. The example used is a BBC Horizon program produced in 1979 and entitled “Elements of Risk”. The film examines the conception, shooting and editing of the program. Begins with a brief discussion of how the same issue is handled by BBC News

results.title: Screening Middlemarch: [19th. century] novel to 90's TV
results.brief_description: Takes the student and the teacher behind the scenes to offer fascinating insights into the complex task of bringing a great 19th Century novel to the television screen. It uses authentic materials from different aspects of the TV and radio production process. It gives opportunities to compare George Eliot’s original text with the radio adaptation, the TV production and the screenwriter’s version, by using excerpts from the actual dramatisation. Allows both teachers and students the opportunity to re-edit some of the shots taken by the production team, and to compare their versions with the broadcast version. It examines the roles of sound effects and music in relation to narrative and realism. This programme will not only teach the process of turning a book into a television serial, but by examining such concepts as narrative, realism, character, gender, class and the use of the authorial voice, will also help students with the study of the novel generally. The kit contains one 90 minute videocassette, one 60 minute audiocassette and one comprehensive activity book.

results.title: Screen sports development workshop
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and Paul Fletcher
results.brief_description:
The SCREENSPORTS event is a unique, entertaining and informative ‘CINEMA EXPERIENCE’. SCREENSPORTS represents an historic leap in the marriage of live performance and technology. It has the potential to be an ACMI flagship pioneering new international standards in screen-based performance. Based on the highly successful Theatre Sports;live improvisation performance the Screensports concept draws on screen culture and the screen as the basis for live improvisation.

A troupe of actors are thrown into virtual worlds utilising the ACMI template sets and the globecaster technology. The actors use these sets as a stimulus for fast and hilarious improvisation.
Screen sports will be fun and informative and appeal to a wide range of people.
In order to develop the Screensports performance it is crucial to conduct a creative development workshop to produce the content for the live performance.
